bestBHT.bht: Paul urges Titus to come to him urgently as he plans to winter in Nicopolis, a potential place for ministry. To replace Titus, Artemas and Tychicus, both trusted ministers of the Gospel, will be sent to Crete. Artemas may have been the bishop of Lystra, while Tychicus was a well-known disciple of Paul. The brethren in Crete are described as unfruitful, indicating the need for new leadership. Scholars debate the location of Nicopolis, but it is likely in Epirus.

Henry Alford: Hasten (make it thine earnest care) to come to me.
Forward on their journey with zeal Zenas the Lawyer.
That nothing may be wanting to them.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Artemas is said to have been subsequently bishop of Lystra.
Tychicus was sent twice by Paul from Rome to Lesser Asia in his first imprisonment (which shows how well qualified he was to become Titus' successor in Crete).
Nicopolis—'the city of victory,' called so from the battle of Actium, in Epirus.
Albert Barnes: This person is not elsewhere mentioned in the New Testament, and nothing more is known of him.
It was at this place, probably, that this epistle was written.

His requesting Titus to leave his important post and to come to him, looks as if his aid were needed in the work of the ministry there, and as if Paul supposed there was a promising field of labor there.
Marvin Vincent: To winter [παραχειμασαι] . Comp. Acts 27:12; Acts 28:11; 1 Corinthians 16:6.
Unfruitful [ακαρποι] . Only here in Pastorals. In Paul, 1 Corinthians 14:14; Eph. verse 11.
Philip Schaff: Titus was soon to be replaced that he might rejoin the apostle.
Artemas is unknown; by tradition, Bishop of Lystra.
Tychicus, of the province of Asia (Acts 20:4), who carried from Rome the letters to Colosse (Colossians 4:7-8), and to Ephesus (so called; see Ephesians 6:21-22).
Archibald T. Robertson: Artemas. Perhaps abbreviation of Artemidorus. Nothing more is known of him.
To Nicopolis. Probably in Epirus, a good place for work in Dalmatia.
John Gill: These were both of them ministers of the Gospel; there is no mention of Artemas anywhere else; some say he was one of the seventy disciples, and that he was afterwards bishop of Lystra; but these are uncertain things.

Hither the apostle would have Titus come to him, after one or other of the above ministers were come to Crete; for as the apostle had the care of all the churches upon him, he would not remove a minister from one place to another, without making a provision in their room.
For I have determined there to winter; that is, to continue there all the winter; not without labour, but to preach the Gospel, and administer the ordinances to the saints there.
John Wesley: Titus was properly an evangelist, who, according to the nature of that office, had no fixed residence; but presided over other elders, wherever he travelled from place to place, assisting each of the apostles according to the measure of his abilities.

Very probably not the Nicopolis in Macedonia, as the vulgar subscription asserts: (indeed, none of those subscriptions at the end of St. Paul's epistles are of any authority:) rather it was a town of the same name which lay upon the sea-coast of Epirus.
Hence it appears, he was not there yet; if so, he would have said, to winter here. Consequently, this letter was not written from thence.

bhtAttempts.bht: Titus is urged to come to Paul urgently as Artemas and Tychicus will be sent to Crete to replace him. It is mentioned that Artemas may have been the bishop of Lystra, while Tychicus was a trusted disciple of Paul. Paul plans to winter in Nicopolis, a place with potential for ministry. The brethren in Crete are described as unfruitful, implying the need for a change in leadership. Scholars debate the location of Nicopolis, but it is likely in Epirus. Titus, being an evangelist, traveled to various places, aiding the apostles as needed. This letter was not written from Nicopolis, suggesting that Titus had not yet arrived there.

Paul urges Titus to come to him urgently as he plans to winter in Nicopolis, a potential place for ministry. To replace Titus, Artemas and Tychicus, both trusted ministers of the Gospel, will be sent to Crete. Artemas may have been the bishop of Lystra, while Tychicus was a well-known disciple of Paul. The brethren in Crete are described as unfruitful, indicating the need for new leadership. Scholars debate the location of Nicopolis, but it is likely in Epirus.

Paul exhorts Titus to hasten and join him urgently, as he plans to winter in Nicopolis, a city known as the city of victory. To replace Titus, Paul intends to send Artemas, possibly a bishop of Lystra, and Tychicus, a well-regarded disciple who was sent by Paul on previous occasions. The brethren in Crete are described as unfruitful, highlighting the need for new leadership. Scholars debate the exact location of Nicopolis, but it is believed to be a suitable place for ministry in Epirus.

Paul urges Titus to come to him urgently as he plans to winter in Nicopolis, a potential place for ministry. To replace Titus, Artemas and Tychicus, trusted ministers of the Gospel, will be sent to Crete. Scholarly debates surround the location of Nicopolis, but it is likely in Epirus. The unfruitfulness of the brethren in Crete implies the need for new leadership. Artemas was possibly the bishop of Lystra, while Tychicus was a well-known disciple of Paul.

Paul implores Titus to come to him with utmost care and urgency, for he plans to winter in Nicopolis, a city famous for the battle of Actium. To replace Titus in Crete, Paul intends to send either Artemas, whose identity remains uncertain, or Tychicus, a trusted disciple known for delivering letters for Paul in the past. The unfruitfulness of the brethren in Crete necessitates new leadership. Although scholars debate the exact location, Nicopolis in Epirus is viewed as a probable choice.
